qas.question: When did Baptist congregations split over slavery?
Why did American Baptist congregations split?
Slaveholders were prevented from being appointed as what?
Who prevented slaveholders from being appointed missionaries?
When did Baptist congregations combine efforts over slavery?
Why did American Baptist congregations work together?
Slaveholders were typically appointed as what?
Who encouraged slaveholders to be appointed missionaries?

context: In <a0_0><b5_0>May 1845<b5_0/><a0_0/>, the Baptist congregations in the United States split <a1_0><b6_0>over slavery and missions<b6_0/><a1_0/>. The <a3_0><b8_0>Home Mission Society<b8_0/><a3_0/> prevented slaveholders from being appointed as <a2_0><b7_0>missionaries<b7_0/><a2_0/>. The split created the Southern Baptist Convention, while the northern congregations formed their own umbrella organization now called the <a4_0><b9_0>American Baptist Churches USA<b9_0/> (ABC-USA)<a4_0/>. The Methodist Episcopal Church, South had recently separated over the issue of slavery, and southern Presbyterians would do so shortly thereafter.
